entry.title: Project Report
entry.summary:
Yelp Data Analysis Project¶

Team Members:

  • Daniel Tong Shen
  • Chenjie Ma
  • Harish Kumar Palaniswamy
  • Samuel Lau

Problem¶

With the yelp academic dataset, we wanted to provide restaurant recommendations to users in the dataset. We used three collaborative filtering methods to provide recommendations:

  • manhattan distance: \[d(x,y) = \sum^n_{k=1}|x_k-y_k|\]

  • euclidean distance: \[d(x,y) = \sqrt{\sum^n_{k=1}{|x_k-y_k|}^2}\]

  • cosine similarity: \[cos(x,y)=\frac{x\cdot y}{\|x\|\times\|y\|} \]

With the help of this website, we were able to implement these methods for our dataset.

To test the relative strength of each method, we calculate the root mean squared error for each user and method.

Data¶

Our data was downloaded from here. It was in a .json format, so it was straightforward to do additional data gathering, cleaning and analysis in python. Afterwards, we filtered the dataset to only food-related reviews and businesses. Then we used the Yelp API to get missing state and city values for certain businesses. The location for each user is assigned by looking at the city they reviewed the most. We end up with the following data structure:

In [3]: 
%%bash
head -21 ../stat133proj2/processed_data/onlyfood_users.txt

{
    "CtXKeKjhT_SQVtgrvn8adQ": {
        "reviews": {
            "_Dc5E16rCL16j2xsUHw18Q": {
                "rating": 4, 
                "state": "NY", 
                "city": "New York"
            }
        }, 
        "location": "Cambridge"
    }, 
    "p0FNClcqkitN3xcJWZOx9w": {
        "reviews": {
            "roEQNfyPi3jRv3WFFr-f_g": {
                "rating": 3, 
                "state": "CA", 
                "city": "La Jolla"
            }
        }, 
        "location": "La Jolla"
    },

After cleaning and processing the data, we performed our analysis using the 3 different filtering methods. Below are the cosine similarity recommendations and the closest user matches for user_ids: 'vOFduWk_HL9ACP_X26dIRg' and 'YeneeAcs8-KVdi00x7hVJA'.

In [10]: 
%%bash
head -10 ../stat133proj2/processed_data/user_matches.json

{
    "vOFduWk_HL9ACP_X26dIRg": {
        "restaraunt_recs": "DARh6yjrGGVZ7R3Gdh4CMA", 
        "city": "Boston", 
        "user_match": "TKPQEd2AVMERKWB3qtTdhw"
    }, 
    "YeneeAcs8-KVdi00x7hVJA": {
        "restaraunt_recs": "VeiGa7h8p1I2yAIfgZjgtw", 
        "city": "Houston", 
        "user_match": "71h2P18M0DLjIDQR7uNlgQ"

Using the matched and processed data, we built a user network that links the top businesses in a city to users that reviewed it. Their recommendations and user matches are found using cosine similarity and follow the structure below:

In [11]: 
%%bash
head -14 ../d3_network/data/Berkeley.json
awk 'NR>=14562 && NR<=14570' ../d3_network/data/Berkeley.json

{
  "nodes": [
    {
      "rest_recs": "", 
      "user_match": "", 
      "user_reviewcount": 1, 
      "_name": "Jonathan G."
    }, 
    {
      "rest_recs": "", 
      "user_match": "", 
      "user_reviewcount": 1, 
      "_name": "Stan A."
    }, 
  "edges": [
    {
      "source": 0, 
      "target": 2426
    }, 
    {
      "source": 1, 
      "target": 2426
    },

Challenges¶

Pearson Correlation Coefficient Method¶

Problems with this method

Parallelizing the Testing Framework¶

Problems with this

Ipython Notebook and D3¶

Due to the size of our network graphs, we weren't able to successfully display it in the ipython notebook. And since we were having problems working out the full functionality our html (switching city graphs by clicking buttons), we decided to uploaded our network here instead. We also did this with the d3 business map.

Other Challenges¶

Description

Results¶

Best Filtering Method¶

In order to check the quality of our predictions, we calculated root mean square errors for each user. To calculate the errors, we found the average of all the absolute differences between a user's predicted ratings for a restaurant and their actual rating. In order to compare the two, we act as if the user didn't go to the business in the first place, and then compare the predicted rating from our collaborative filtering and the actual value. Here's the formula for each user:

\[{rms\:error}=\sqrt{\frac{\sum{(actual\:rating-predicted\:rating)}^2}{n}} \] where \(n\) is the number of ratings a user has.

Below is a comparison of the errors for each collaborative filtering method.

In [22]: 
%load_ext rmagic

The rmagic extension is already loaded. To reload it, use:
  %reload_ext rmagic
In [27]: 
%%R -w 800 -h 500

df = read.csv('../stat133proj2/processed_data/errors.csv', header=F)
colnames(df) = c('User', 'Cosine Errors', 'Euclidean Errors', 'Manhattan Errors')

# reshape the variables to long
library(reshape)
data = melt(df, id='User')

library(ggplot2)

ggplot(data, aes(x=value, colour=variable)) + geom_density() + ggtitle("Recommendation Systems") + theme(plot.title = element_text(face="bold"))
In [29]: 
%%R -w 600 -h 400

ggplot(data, aes(x=variable, y=value, fill=variable)) + geom_boxplot() + ggtitle("Recommendation Systems")

From above plots, you can see that the Cosine Method produces the smallest errors, with the Euclidean and Manhattan methods producing almost identifical errors. We use the Cosine Method to find matches and restaurant recommendations for the d3 user and business network.

User and Business Network Visualization¶

Due to issues with using ipython notebook and d3 (detailed in Problems section), we uploaded our user and business network here. Doing this involves uploading the index.html, javascript files, and data files here. You can see that each user is link to a one or more of the top 5 businesses in Berkeley, New York, Houston or Boston. Hovering your cursor over each node gives you information on each business or user.

In addition to the user network, we used d3 and googlemaps to plot out the businesses in our dataset. The visualization can be found here.

Team members responsible for this notebook:

  • team member 1 Samuel Lau: describe, comment on, and present results
In [8]: 
%%bash
ipython nbconvert NB4_project_report.ipynb --to latex
pdflatex NB4_project_report.tex

In this notebook, you'll sumarize your finding for the class presentation.

The class presentation will use this notebook in slide mode, as I do during lecture time.

You'll need to download the following zip file, unzip it, and run the following notebook install-support.ipynb to install the slide capabilities.

The notebook notebook-slideshow-example.ipynb will give you examples on how to use slides within the iPython notebook.

You should also write this notebook so that you can convert it nicely into a pdf document using the commands

ipython nbconvert NB4_report.pynb --to latex
pdflatex NB4_report.tex

See here for further references on how to do that.

In this notebook, you'll

  • describe your problem as stated in the propectus

  • comment on your data sources, on their format, on the difficulties to get them

  • present the main challenge you encountered

  • present your finding in the form of expresive graphics

Be sure to include an introduction section motivating your visualizations, with a description of the substantive context and why it is interesting.

Cite the source of the data and any other references that you used in carrying out your project.

entry.title: Data Analysis
entry.summary:
In this notebook, you'll perform the actual analysis of the data stored in the directory

./data/cleaned

If the data is not ready yet (e.g. the other members of the team in charge of cleaning the data are not done yet), you may want to simulate cleaned data in the form you want them to be in order to perform the analysis. This may also help you data cleaning team to come up with the rigth data frame. If you choose to do so, store your simulated data into the directory

./data/simulated

Having performed analysis of simulated data may help you with the analysis of the actual data, since you will be able to notice deviations between the real and simulated data, which may be worth explaining and investigating further.

The graphics your going to produce as a result of your analysis should be store in the directory:

./visualization

Team members responsible for this notebook:

List the team members contributing to this notebook, along with their responsabilities:

  • team member 1 name: team member 1 responsabilities
  • team member 2 name: team member 2 responsabilities
  • etc.

I advise you to work at least in pairs for each project notebook, as you did for the homework assignments. Of course, all team members may participate to each notebook.

entry.title: Data Cleaning
entry.summary:
In this notebook, you'll

  • load the raw data into R or Pandas dataframe from the ./data/raw directory using the functions and classes (written during the data gathering phase) in the ./script directory

  • perform visual exploration on your data variables to detect anomalies, errors, outliers, interesting features etc.

  • clean categorical and quantitative variables (by removing observations and variables with too many missing values, by consolidating categorical variables, by selecting an appropriate subset of variables and observations for later analysis, etc.)

  • save the cleaned data into csv files in the ./data/cleaned directory

  • save interesting graphics you obtained during visual exploration into the ./visualiation directory

Team members responsible for this notebook:

List the team members contributing to this notebook, along with their responsabilities:

  • Harish Kumar: team member 1 responsabilities
  • team member 2 name: team member 2 responsabilities

START

As mentioned before, since we only want the food-related reviews, we have to filter out the non-food related businesses from the reviews. We can do this by first defining a list of categories which are considered to be associated with food. Then, create a list of

In [15]: 
import json

def is_food_related(business):
    if business["categories"] == None:
        return False
    categories = ["Food", "Buffets", "Creperies", "Juice Bars & Smoothies", "Candy Stores", "Diners", "Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt","Coffee & Tea", 
                  "Cafes", "Bagels", "Bakeries", "Sandwiches", "Desserts", "Food Stands", "Street Vendors", "Ethnic Food", "Vegetarian", "Breakfast & Brunch" ]
    for x in categories:
        if x in business["categories"]:
            return True
    return False


def get_food_businesses(location = r'./data/cleaned/businesses.txt'):
    with open(location, 'rb') as infile:
        businesses = json.loads(infile)
    return businesses


def filter_businesses(users, businesses):
    for user in users.keys():
        for business_id in users[user]["reviews"].keys():
            if (not is_food_related(businesses[business_id])):
                del users[user]["reviews"][business_id]
            else:
                users[user]["reviews"][business_id]["state"] = businesses[business_id]["state"] 
                users[user]["reviews"][business_id]["name"] = businesses[business_id]["name"] 
                users[user]["reviews"][business_id]["categories"] = businesses[business_id]["categories"] 
                users[user]["reviews"][business_id]["city"] = businesses[business_id]["city"] 
        if users[user]["reviews"] == {}:
            del users[user]
    return users

def main():
    with open(r'../data/cleaned/users1.txt', 'r') as infile:
        users = json.load(infile)
    with open(r'../data/cleaned/businesses.txt', 'r') as infile2:
        businesses = json.load(infile2)
    
    users = filter_businesses(users, businesses)
    
    with open(r'../data/cleaned/users2.txt', 'w') as outfile1:
        json.dump(users, outfile1, indent=4)

    
    
main()

Now, in order to see the concentration of users among geographical locations, we have to compute the location for each user. This is done by assuming that a user's reviews would be concentrated in businesses where he/she resides. For example, if user1 reviews 5 restaurants in New York but only 1 from San Francisco, it can be assumed that user1's location is New York.

In [22]: 
import operator

def compute_user_locations(location):
    with open(location, 'r') as infile1:
        users = json.load(infile1)

    user_locations = {}
    for user in users.keys():
        location_count = {}
        for business in users[user]["reviews"].keys():
            business_location = users[user]["reviews"][business]["city"]
            if location_count.has_key(business_location):
                location_count[business_location] += 1
            else:
                location_count[business_location] = 1
        location = max(location_count.iteritems(), key=operator.itemgetter(1))[0]
        user_locations[user] = location

    for user in users:
        users[user]["location"] = user_locations[user]
    return users

def main():
    input_location = r'../data/cleaned/users2.txt'
    output_location = r'../data/cleaned/users3.txt'
    users = compute_user_locations(input_location)
    with open(output_location, 'w') as outfile1:
        json.dump(users, outfile1, indent=4)

main()

Now, we can see that each user has a "location" field in addition to their "reviews" field.

In [24]: 
%%bash
head -n 20 ../data/cleaned/users3.txt

{
    "gMAncN40yUEnciPNd-eZAA": {
        "reviews": {
            "6nOxwnuN0ZwLX3h3JYSJnA": {
                "rating": 4, 
                "state": "NY", 
                "name": "Tom's Restaurant", 
                "categories": [
                    "Diners"
                ], 
                "city": "New York"
            }
        }, 
        "location": "New York"
    }, 
    "CtXKeKjhT_SQVtgrvn8adQ": {
        "reviews": {
            "_Dc5E16rCL16j2xsUHw18Q": {
                "rating": 4, 
                "state": "NY",

END

entry.title: Data Gathering
entry.summary:
In this notebook, you'll

  • create the directory structure for your project
  • download the raw data for your project
  • write functions and classes to transform raw data (e.g in XML, jason, etc.) into data frames
  • explain what your are doing

Team members responsible for this notebook:

Harish Kumar Palaniswamy

Creating initial folders for storing data

In [5]: 
%%bash
mkdir ../data ../data/raw ../data/cleaned

dir

NB1_data_gathering.ipynb  NB3_data_analysis.ipynb   README.md
NB2_data_cleaning.ipynb   NB4_project_report.ipynb


mkdir: cannot create directory ../data: File exists
mkdir: cannot create directory ../data/raw: File exists
mkdir: cannot create directory ../data/cleaned: File exists

Raw Data

The dataset is a single gzip-compressed file, composed of one json-object per line. Every object contains a 'type' field, which tells you whether it is a business, a user, or a review.

In [19]: 
import json, pprint
rawdata_location = "../data/raw/yelp_academic_dataset.json"
fp = open(rawdata_location)
for i,line in enumerate(fp):
    if (i==0):
        user = json.loads(line)
        #print "User: ", user
    elif (i==474233):
        business = json.loads(line)
        #print "\n\n\Business: ", line
    elif (i==400000):
        review = json.loads(line)
        #print "\n\n Review: ", review

User

User objects contain aggregate information about a single user across all of Yelp (including businesses and reviews not in this dataset)

{ 'type': 'user', 'user_id': (unique user identifier), 'name': (first name, last initial, like 'Matt J.'), 'review_count': (review count), 'average_stars': (floating point average, like 4.31), 'votes': { 'useful': (count of useful votes across all reviews), 'funny': (count of funny votes across all reviews), 'cool': (count of cool votes across all reviews) } }
In [22]: 
user
Out[22]:
{u'average_stars': 3.2258064516129,
 u'name': u'LiiLii C.',
 u'review_count': 31,
 u'type': u'user',
 u'url': u'http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=JkeCKyEaQlbLd9uZYl4DjA',
 u'user_id': u'JkeCKyEaQlbLd9uZYl4DjA',
 u'votes': {u'cool': 18, u'funny': 15, u'useful': 48}}

Business

Business objects contain basic information about local businesses. The 'business_id' field can be used with the Yelp API. The fields are as follows,

{ 'type': 'business', 'business_id': (a unique identifier for this business), 'name': (the full business name), 'neighborhoods': (a list of neighborhood names, might be empty), 'full_address': (localized address), 'city': (city), 'state': (state), 'latitude': (latitude), 'longitude': (longitude), 'stars': (star rating, rounded to half-stars), 'review_count': (review count), 'photo_url': (photo url), 'categories': [(localized category names)] 'open': (is the business still open for business?), 'schools': (nearby universities), 'url': (yelp url) }
In [84]: 
business
Out[84]:
{u'business_id': u'iWMe4FQkftu4fzOyzd0dSQ',
 u'categories': [u'Shopping', u'Local Flavor', u'Toy Stores'],
 u'city': u'San Luis Obispo',
 u'full_address': u'786 Higuera St\nSan Luis Obispo, CA 93401',
 u'latitude': 35.2797924,
 u'longitude': -120.6632318,
 u'name': u'Turn to Nature',
 u'neighborhoods': [],
 u'open': True,
 u'photo_url': u'http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/DsER4g1PUYwY2-PLpYsAnw/ms.jpg',
 u'review_count': 2,

 u'url': u'http://www.yelp.com/biz/turn-to-nature-san-luis-obispo'}

Review¶

Review objects contain the review text, the star rating, and information on votes Yelp users have cast on the review. We can use user_id to associate a particular review with others by the same user. Likewise, we can use business_id to associate this review with others of the same business.

{ 'type': 'test' 'type': 'review', 'business_id': (the identifier of the reviewed business), 'user_id': (the identifier of the authoring user), 'stars': (star rating, integer 1-5), 'text': (review text), 'date': (date, formatted like '2011-04-19'), 'votes': { 'useful': (count of useful votes), 'funny': (count of funny votes), 'cool': (count of cool votes) } }

In [85]: 
review
Out[85]:
{u'business_id': u'huHxwjbkyEf1nTam-o2BOQ',
 u'date': u'2012-03-22',
 u'review_id': u'AtxcKzzazdxLXcUocUDlaw',
 u'stars': 5,
 u'text': u"Delicious, Fast and Healthy. I've been looking for a restaurant like this for a long time. I really like the pickled veggies and pork.",
 u'type': u'review',
 u'user_id': u'XbNUd-QY3h22VH9Y9mSywg',
 u'votes': {u'cool': 0, u'funny': 0, u'useful': 0}}

Since the reviews contain the user ids and business ids, we only need the review objects and thus, can get rid of the review and user objects. Also, we can now group each reviews by their user id so that we can easily see the reviews for each particular user.

In [23]: 
import json
rawdata_location = "../data/raw/yelp_academic_dataset.json"
def read_yelpdata(location = "../data/raw/yelp_academic_dataset.json"):
    users = {}

    with open(location, 'rb') as infile:
        for line in infile:
            item = json.loads(line) #read each object line by line
            if item['type'] == 'business':
                pass #ignore business objects
            elif item['type'] == 'review':
                business_id = item['business_id']
                user_id = item['user_id']
                rating = item['stars']
                
                
                if users.has_key(user_id):
                    users[user_id]["reviews"][business_id] = {"rating":rating}
                else:
                    users[user_id] = {}
                    users[user_id]["reviews"] = {}
                    users[user_id]["reviews"][business_id] = {"rating": rating}
            elif item['type'] == 'user':
                pass #ignore user objects as well 
            else:
                #should never trigger
                raise ValueError("Unknown type")
        return users
    

def main():
    users = read_yelpdata()
    print "Processed {0} users".format(len(users.keys()))
    with open('../data/cleaned/users1.txt', 'w') as outfile:
        json.dump(users, outfile, indent=4, sort_keys=True)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

Processed 130873 users

The data dumped is of the form is of the following schema

{

"user_id": {
        "business_id": Rating that user left for business associated with this business ID, from 1-5

}

}

Getting Business Information from Yelp API

After getting rid of the user and business objects. However, the business ids in the review objects are not all in our dataset, in fact, most of them are not in our dataset. Thus we need to obtain information for each business_id in the reviews using the Yelp API. Namely, for each business_id, we need to obtain its name, categories, city, state (see above for a refresher on the types of fields in business objects).

Below is an example of the JSON of the API's response and code to generate a response from a known business id.

Note: Running the full API script below takes at least 1 hour also one needs to make sure the API credentials(consumer_key, consumer_secret, token, token_secret) have not been used in the past 24 hours.

In [3]: 
import json
import oauth2
import optparse
import urllib
import urllib2
import time
import os

def request(host, path, url_params, consumer_key, consumer_secret, token, token_secret):
  """Returns response for API request."""
  # Unsigned URL
  encoded_params = ''
  if url_params:
    encoded_params = urllib.urlencode(url_params)
  url = 'http://%s%s?%s' % (host, path, encoded_params)
  #print 'URL: %s' % (url,)

  # Sign the URL
  consumer = oauth2.Consumer(consumer_key, consumer_secret)
  oauth_request = oauth2.Request('GET', url, {})
  oauth_request.update({'oauth_nonce': oauth2.generate_nonce(),
                        'oauth_timestamp': oauth2.generate_timestamp(),
                        'oauth_token': token,
                        'oauth_consumer_key': consumer_key})

  token = oauth2.Token(token, token_secret)
  oauth_request.sign_request(oauth2.SignatureMethod_HMAC_SHA1(), consumer, token)
  signed_url = oauth_request.to_url()
  #print 'Signed URL: %s\n' % (signed_url,)

  # Connect
  try:
    conn = urllib2.urlopen(signed_url, None)
    try:
      response = json.loads(conn.read())
    finally:
      conn.close()
  except urllib2.HTTPError, error:
    response = json.loads(error.read())
    print response
    return 0
  except urllib2.URLError, error:
    response = json.loads(error.read())
    print response
    return 0

  if response.has_key("error"):
      print response
      return 0
  else:
      return response

def get_business_info():
    print "Running..."
    start_time = time.time()
    host = "api.yelp.com"
    base_path = "/v2/business/"
    url_params = {}
    #consumer_key = "hdFjqcPRZyZ0eqi26af3tw"
    #consumer_secret = "Ex5U5ZJflQb-tx4T0AJiyKKf1yM"
    #token = "-w0vkTLODYebA_4PrEer9T48bHB_TD1S"
    #token_secret = "PZnOemFP0TJbkzLKQsBn8lNO3U8"
    
    location =  "../data/cleaned/users1.txt"  #location of "cleaned" data so far
    outputFile = "../data/cleaned/businesses.txt" #location of output JSON file containing business info 

    businesses = {}
    with open(location, 'rb') as infile:
        users = json.load(infile)
        users_processed = 0
        for user in users.keys():
            users_processed += 1
            reviews = users[user]["reviews"]
            business_ids = reviews.keys()
            print business_ids
            return 0
            for business_id in business_ids:
                if (not businesses.has_key(business_id)):
                    businesses[business_id] = {}
                else:
                    pass

    print "Need to obtain info for {0} businesses".format(len(businesses.keys()))
    i=0
    for business_id in businesses.keys():
        i+=1
        if (i % 200) == 0:
            print i
        path = base_path + business_id
        response = request(host, path, url_params, consumer_key, consumer_secret, token, token_secret)
        try:
            city, state, categories, name = (None, None, None, None)
            if (response != 0):
                if response.has_key("location"):
                    if response["location"].has_key("city"):
                        city = response["location"]["city"]
                    if response["location"].has_key("state_code"):
                        state = response["location"]["state_code"]
                if response.has_key("categories"):
                    categories = [x[0] for x in response["categories"]]
                if response.has_key("name"):
                    name = response["name"]
            businesses[business_id]["city"] = city           
            businesses[business_id]["state"] =  state
            businesses[business_id]["name"] = name
            businesses[business_id]["categories"] = categories
        except KeyError, e:
            print response, "\n\n\n"
            print "Failed : ", business_id
            print repr(e)
    with open(outputFile, 'w') as outfile:
        json.dump(businesses, outfile, indent=4)
    elapsed_time = time.time() - start_time
    print "Elapsed Time: ", elapsed_time, " s"

print consumer_secret
get_business_info()
